{"post_stream":{"posts":[{"id":2989923,"name":"Roger","username":"RogerMCT","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/rogermct/{size}/265955_2.png","created_at":"2022-01-12T15:19:18.356Z","cooked":"

Can you use a T-fitting and run two pneumatic pistons off one solenoid?

","post_number":1,"post_type":1,"posts_count":8,"updated_at":"2022-01-12T15:19:18.356Z","reply_count":1,"reply_to_post_number":null,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":85,"reads":167,"readers_count":166,"score":463.4,"yours":false,"topic_id":399895,"topic_slug":"pneumatic-question-2-pistons-1-solenoid","display_username":"Roger","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":"","bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":31466,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":""},"post_url":"/t/pneumatic-question-2-pistons-1-solenoid/399895/1","custom_user_title":null,"reactions":[],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":0,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null,"can_vote":false},{"id":2989928,"name":"Jim Forbes","username":"MrForbes","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/mrforbes/{size}/165505_2.png","created_at":"2022-01-12T15:21:46.617Z","cooked":"

I’ve never seen a rule prohibiting the practice, so we do it often. If the thing needs to move quickly, it will limit the airflow compared to using two solenoid valves.

","post_number":2,"post_type":1,"posts_count":8,"updated_at":"2022-01-12T15:22:32.184Z","reply_count":0,"reply_to_post_number":null,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":0,"reads":165,"readers_count":164,"score":63.0,"yours":false,"topic_id":399895,"topic_slug":"pneumatic-question-2-pistons-1-solenoid","display_username":"Jim Forbes","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":"","bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[{"id":2,"count":2}],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":6260,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":"Jim Forbes 1726 Mechanical Mentor"},"post_url":"/t/pneumatic-question-2-pistons-1-solenoid/399895/2","custom_user_title":"Jim Forbes 1726 Mechanical Mentor","reactions":[{"id":"heart","type":"emoji","count":2}],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":2,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null},{"id":2989931,"name":"Nick Matthes ","username":"nmatthes","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/nmatthes/{size}/193329_2.png","created_at":"2022-01-12T15:22:57.458Z","cooked":"
RogerMCT:

Can you use a T-fitting and run two pneumatic pistons off one solenoid?

Yeah, 4130 almost always does this. Especially if it’s for dropping down an intake, the cylinders for both sides is off of one solenoid.

EDIT: Also worth noting that if you want them to drop down at the same time, try to make the air line run as close to identical as possible.

","post_number":3,"post_type":1,"posts_count":8,"updated_at":"2022-01-12T16:40:01.057Z","reply_count":0,"reply_to_post_number":null,"quote_count":1,"incoming_link_count":4,"reads":163,"readers_count":162,"score":127.6,"yours":false,"topic_id":399895,"topic_slug":"pneumatic-question-2-pistons-1-solenoid","display_username":"Nick Matthes ","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":2,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":"","bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[{"id":2,"count":3}],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":25311,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":""},"post_url":"/t/pneumatic-question-2-pistons-1-solenoid/399895/3","custom_user_title":null,"reactions":[{"id":"heart","type":"emoji","count":3}],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":3,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null},{"id":2989993,"name":"Stewart Riley","username":"Strategic","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/strategic/{size}/10157_2.png","created_at":"2022-01-12T16:14:48.956Z","cooked":"

Both the above answers have the right idea. It’s perfectly legal to do this and often a good idea if you’re trying to run two actuators in sync for something like an intake, climb, or other mechanism where the coordination of the two actuators is very important. Using only one solenoid insures that they will work in perfect coordination. But, as is also noted, you are splitting the available airflow between the actuators, so if this is a high power application, you might want to go with two solenoids and work through the more difficult task of coordinating their actions.

No but you can run two cylinders with one solenoid.

This message is brought to you by AGOMWHIWPCTP

A grumpy old man who hates it when people call them pistons

The pistons in the cylinders are what get run by the solenoid valves, so I let the terminology slide

","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/indysam/{size}/111341_2.png"},"bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[{"id":2,"count":3}],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":6260,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":"Jim Forbes 1726 Mechanical Mentor"},"post_url":"/t/pneumatic-question-2-pistons-1-solenoid/399895/6","custom_user_title":"Jim Forbes 1726 Mechanical Mentor","reactions":[{"id":"heart","type":"emoji","count":2},{"id":"point_up","type":"emoji","count":1}],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":3,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null},{"id":2990056,"name":"wgorgen","username":"wgorgen","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/wgorgen/{size}/10106_2.png","created_at":"2022-01-12T17:19:32.423Z","cooked":"
Strategic:

But, as is also noted, you are splitting the available airflow between the actuators, so if this is a high power application, you might want to go with two solenoids and work through the more difficult task of coordinating their actions.

Just to clarify for the OP; both cylinders will get the same pressure air, so the force applied by the cylinders is not degraded by splitting the air between the two cylinders. The time that it takes for the air to fill the volume as the piston moves in the cylinder is what will take longer assuming that your solenoid is the “choke point” for the airflow.

In my experience, the airflow from the tanks to the manifold can be just as restricted as the passage through the solenoid. So, often times splitting the airflow between two solenoids does not really improve the time it takes for the cylinders to actuate very much since the same total air needs to come from the tanks to the manifold.

If actuation time is critical and you are using large cylinders that consume a lot of air (and therefore actuate relatively slowly) then it is worth testing two separate solenoid valves to see if you get better speed than just one.
